elements.content: Three new 2D complexes were constructed by reaction of Co(NO3)2·6H2O with 4,4′-((5-carboxy-1,3-phenylene)bis(oxy))dibenzoic acid (H3cpbda) in three different solvents (N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF), N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA), and N-methylpyrrolidinone (DMP)), formulated as {[Co1.5(cpbda)(DMF)(H2O)3]·(DMF)} n (1), {[Co1.5(cpbda)(DMA)(H2O)3]·(DMA)} n (2), and {[Co1.5(cpbda)(DMP)(H2O)3]·(DMP)} n (3). Complexes were characterized by X-ray single-crystal diffraction, elemental analysis (EA), powder x-ray diffraction (PXRD), infrared spectra (IR), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The solvents (DMF, DMA, and DMP) were incorporated in the final supramolecular structures, respectively, giving rise to three similar 2D frameworks. However, the special active replaceable coordination sites in the 1D channel were also discovered. The synthesis procedure was sensitive to small molecular carbonyl solvents (DMF, DMA, and DMP), but the hydroxy (methanol and alcohol) was not identified. The different coordinated and latticed solvent molecules in 1–3 propped up the varisized pore structures. By comparing the sizes of the 1D parallelogram channel in complexes 1–3, we found that the sizes of the channels (76.84 Å2 of 3 > 74.37 Å2 of 2 > 72.76 Å2 of 1) are induced by the sizes of the solvent molecules (DMP > DMA > DMF), and good chemical stability of 1–3 was observed. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicated that complexes 1–3 exhibited antiferromagnetic coupling between adjacent Co(II) ions.

elements.content: Design and construction of the porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are extremely attractive, due to their potential applications in gas storage, separation, heterogeneous catalysis, and ion exchange. Generally, the application behaviors of PCPs were found directly associated with the shape and size of the channels, so how to control the shape and size of the channels becomes a great challenge in synthesis of PCPs. As it is known, there are several key factors that can influence the construction of PCPs, such as selection of ligands, pH values, solvents, temperatures, etc. In particular, the solvent or template is a crucial factor, for their chemical properties can influence the crystal growth rate and final structures. Recently, the solvent size reported can dramatically influence the pore size in PCPs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Design and construction of the porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are extremely attractive, due to their potential applications in gas storage, separation, heterogeneous catalysis, and ion exchange. Generally, the application behaviors of PCPs were found directly associated with the shape and size of the channels, so how to control the shape and size of the channels becomes a great challenge in synthesis of PCPs. As it is known, there are several key factors that can influence the construction of PCPs, such as selection of ligands, pH values, solvents, temperatures, etc. In particular, the solvent or template is a crucial factor, for their chemical properties can influence the crystal growth rate and final structures. Recently, the solvent size reported can dramatically influence the pore size in PCPs.

elements.content: Three-dimensional (3D) PCPs have been largely studied because of the strong framework rigidity after removal of the guest molecules. On the contrary, when the template guests are removed, the low-dimensional frameworks, which crystallize via the hydrogen bonds, π–π interactions, and van der Waals interactions, easily collapse. However, sometimes the 2D PCPs are significant motifs in guest adsorption/desorption because of their tunable flexibility, typical structural contraction in a 2D pillared-bilayer, reversible sliding of 2D grids, and interdigitated network dominated by the filled guest molecules in the voids.
elements.clean_text: Three-dimensional (3D) PCPs have been largely studied because of the strong framework rigidity after removal of the guest molecules. On the contrary, when the template guests are removed, the low-dimensional frameworks, which crystallize via the hydrogen bonds, π-π interactions, and van der Waals interactions, easily collapse. However, sometimes the 2D PCPs are significant motifs in guest adsorption/desorption because of their tunable flexibility, typical structural contraction in a 2D pillared-bilayer, reversible sliding of 2D grids, and interdigitated network dominated by the filled guest molecules in the voids.

elements.content: On the basis of the previous works on the crystal design and construction, the triangular shaped 4,4′-((5-carboxy-1,3-phenylene)bis(oxy))dibenzoic acid (H3cpbda) is chosen as the building block to construct PCPs not only because the three benzene rings in H3cpbda can better brace the space, which is a benefit for the formation of PCPs, but also because the −O– motif can rotate and distort to adopt different coordinated configurations. Lots of researches focus on structures and properties of cobaltic metal–orgaic frameworks (MOFs). In this work, we used the H3cpbda and cobalt nitrate constructed three new 2D porous complexes by solvothermal syntheses, namely, {[Co1.5(cpbda)(DMF)(H2O)3]·(DMF)} n (1), {[Co1.5(cpbda)(DMA)(H2O)3]·(DMA)} n (2), and {[Co1.5(cpbda)(DMP)(H2O)3]·(DMP)} n (3). The solvent size influences and magnetic properties were also discussed.

elements.content: All the solvents and reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. Infrared spectra were obtained in KBr discs on a Bruker EQUINOX-55 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N atoms were determined with a Perkin-Elmer 2400C Elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu–Kα, 1.5418 Å). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in a nitrogen stream using a Seiko Extar 6000 TG/DTA equipment with heating rate of 5 °C·min–1. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer. The experimental susceptibilities were corrected for the diamagnetism of the constituent atoms (Pascal′s tables). Variable-temperature PXRD was carried out with a Shimadzu XRD-7000 X-ray diffractometer using Cu–Kα radiation (0.15418 nm).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All the solvents and reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. Infrared spectra were obtained in KBr discs on a Bruker EQUINOX-55 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N atoms were determined with a Perkin-Elmer 2400C Elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu-Kα, 1.5418 Å). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in a nitrogen stream using a Seiko Extar 6000 TG/DTA equipment with heating rate of 5 °C⋅min-1. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer. The experimental susceptibilities were corrected for the diamagnetism of the constituent atoms (Pascal's tables). Variable-temperature PXRD was carried out with a Shimadzu XRD-7000 X-ray diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation (0.15418 nm).

elements.content: Single-crystal diffraction data of 1–3 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The structures were solved using direct methods and successive Fourier difference synthesis (SHELXS-97) and refined using the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all nonhydrogen atoms (SHELXL-97). The hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were placed in calculated positions and refined using a riding on attached atoms with isotropic thermal parameters 1.2 times those of their carrier atoms. PLATON reveals the presence of solvent accessible voids in the crystal lattice, indicating solvent occupancy. However, the highly disordered lattice DMF molecules were not located and included in structure refinements in 2. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for 1–3 are listed in Tables and S1, . Crystallographic data for the structural analysis have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center. CCDC reference numbers are 887267 for 1, 887266 for 2, and 887268 for 3.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Data Collection and Refinement

Single-crystal diffraction data of 1-3 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The structures were solved using direct methods and successive Fourier difference synthesis (SHELXS-97) and refined using the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all nonhydrogen atoms (SHELXL-97). The hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were placed in calculated positions and refined using a riding on attached atoms with isotropic thermal parameters 1.2 times those of their carrier atoms. PLATON reveals the presence of solvent accessible voids in the crystal lattice, indicating solvent occupancy. However, the highly disordered lattice DMF molecules were not located and included in structure refinements in 2. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for 1-3 are listed in Tables  and S1, . Crystallographic data for the structural analysis have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center. CCDC reference numbers are 887267 for 1, 887266 for 2, and 887268 for 3.

elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Crystal Structure

Using various small molecule solvents (DMF, DMA, and DMP), complexes 1-3 are obtained by the solvothermal reactions of 4,4'-((5-carboxy-1,3-phenylene)bis(oxy))dibenzoic acid and Co(NO3)2 (in 4:3 molar ratio) (Scheme ). Three synthesis routes exhibit highly synthesized yield and purity.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that 1 crystallizes in monoclinic system with P21 /n space group. The asymmetric unit contains two independent Co(II) cations, two deprotonated cpbda ligand, one coordinated DMF, three coordinated water molecules, and one lattice DMF molecule. As shown in Figure a, the Co1 bonds with six oxygen atoms from two cpbda ligands, three water molecules, and one DMF molecule, forming a distorted CoO6 octahedron. The Co2 is also octahedrally coordinated by six oxygen atoms from four cpbda ligands and two water molecules. The Co–O bonds distances range from 2.036(2) (Co1–O7) to 2.195(3) (Co1–O1w) Å, the bond angles of around Co(II) cations are in the range of 80.73(9) to 180.000(1)°.

elements.content: The 2D complexes 1–3 possess the similar skeletons (Figure c). Three Co(II) were bridged by water molecules (O1w) to be a three nuclear clusters, then were connected with six cpbda ligands around, extending to be the 2D layer. The cpbda ligand coordinate with four metal ions can be simplified as a four-connected node. The Co1 and Co2 are two-connected and four-connected nodes. The 2D structure of 1–3 can be described as a (3,4,6)-network with the Point symbol of (3·4·5·62·7)2(3·6·7)2(32·42·52·62·76·9), in Figure d. View along the c axis, the 1D parallelogram channels are shown in 3D framework, with the dimensions of approximately 6.8 × 10.7 Å2 (including van der Walls radii of the atoms) (Figure b) .

The asymmetric unit is similar to that of 1, and all the DMF are instead by DMA molecules in 2, as shown in Figure a. The Co–O bonds distances are 2.045(3) (Co1–O9) and 2.195(3) (Co1–O1w) Å; the bond angles around Co(II) cations are in the range of 81.06(14) to 180.00(16)°. Along the c axis, the dimensions of 1D parallelogram channels in 2 is approximately 6.7 × 11.1 Å2 (including van der Walls radii of the atoms) (Figure b).

The asymmetric unit is similar to that of 1, and all the DMF are instead by DMA molecules in 2, as shown in Figure a. The Co-O bonds distances are 2.045(3) (Co1-O9) and 2.195(3) (Co1-O1w) Å; the bond angles around Co(II) cations are in the range of 81.06(14) to 180.00(16)°. Along the c axis, the dimensions of 1D parallelogram channels in 2 is approximately 6.7 × 11.1 Å2 (including van der Walls radii of the atoms) (Figure b).

elements.content: Surprisingly, an active replaceable coordinated site is found in such a skeleton. The synthesis procedure is sensitive to small molecular carbonyl solvents (DMF, DMA, and DMP) (Figure ). Coordinated abilities of other hydroxy solvents also have been investigated. Under the same synthesis conditions and solvent ratio, we have tried methanol and alcohol with various temperatures, but no crystals were synthesized, and the hydroxy is not identified. We conjectured that the coordinated ability of carbonyl is stronger than the hydroxy.

PXRD Results

To confirm the phase purity of the bulk materials at room temperature (Figure S4-S6, ), PXRD experiments have been carried out for 1-3. Although the experimental patterns show several slightly deviated diffraction peaks in comparison to the simulated patterns based on the crystal data, the synthesized crystals of 1-3 are still regarded as the pure phases.

elements.content: To identify the thermal stabilities of 1–3, the TGA measurements are carried out (Figure a). The curves show that the structure of 2 is thermally stable until 100 °C and that 1 and 3 are thermally stable until 110 °C. For complex 1, a weight loss of 29.5% (calcd. 29.6%) is observed from 110 to 360 °C, which is attributed to the loss of three coordinated water molecules and two DMF molecules, after 390 °C organic components quickly break down. For 2, the weight loss of 31.8% between 100 and 370 °C is corresponding to the loss of three water molecules; one lattice and one coordinated DMA molecules are lost (calcd. 32.4%), and then rapid decomposition of 2 at 390 °C is observed. The curve of 3 shows that coordinated three water molecules and two DMP molecules are lost at the range of 110 and 340 °C, (obsd. 34.6%; calcd. 34.7%). Up to 380 °C, the organic components decomposed, and complex 1 was chosen, with the nitrogen atmosphere, slowly heated up to 150, 180, 200, 300, and 400 °C, and the temperatures were constant for 2 h. The IR analyses of five heated samples (Figure b) prove that the DMF molecules have not fully went out at a high temperature up to 200 °C, and the variable-temperature PXRD analyses of 1 (Figure S12, ) prove that the 2D porous structure was destroyed before 130 °C; the DMF molecules have not went out. So, the desolvations of 1–3 can hardly be realized to obtain porous 2D structures, and the gas adsorptions have not been further explored.

elements.content: The antiferromagnetic magnetic behaviors of 1–3 are shown in Figure . The magnetic susceptibilities, χM, of 1–3 were measured in the 2–300 K temperature range. At room temperature, χM T of 1–3 are equal to 4.75, 4.58, and 4.70 cm3 mol–1K, respectively. The values are higher than the value of 3.75 cm3 mol–1K based on two isolated spin-only Co(II) because of the contributions to the susceptibility from orbital angular momentum at high temperature. As the temperature changes from room temperature to 2 K, the χM T values of 1–3 continuously decrease; at 2 K, χM T values of 1.66, 1.63, and 1.89 cm3 mol–1 K are observed. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibilities (1/χM) of 1–3 obey the Curie–Weiss law with χM = C/(T – θ), with θ = −9.47 K, C = 5.51 cm3 mol–1 K, and R = 0.9991 for 1. Like that, θ = −9.91 K, C = 4.73 cm3 mol–1 K, and R = 0.9991 for 2; and θ = −7.98 K, C = 4.83 cm3 mol–1 K, and R = 0.9994 for 3. The moderate negative θ values indicate the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions among adjacent Co(II) ions even if a contribution from the spin–orbit coupling of Co(II) is also present.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The antiferromagnetic magnetic behaviors of 1-3 are shown in Figure . The magnetic susceptibilities, χM, of 1-3 were measured in the 2-300 K temperature range. At room temperature, χM T of 1-3 are equal to 4.75, 4.58, and 4.70 cm3 mol-1K, respectively. The values are higher than the value of 3.75 cm3 mol-1K based on two isolated spin-only Co(II) because of the contributions to the susceptibility from orbital angular momentum at high temperature. As the temperature changes from room temperature to 2 K, the χM T values of 1-3 continuously decrease; at 2 K, χM T values of 1.66, 1.63, and 1.89 cm3 mol-1 K are observed. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibilities (1/χM) of 1-3 obey the Curie-Weiss law with χM = C/(T - θ), with θ = -9.47 K, C = 5.51 cm3 mol-1 K, and R = 0.9991 for 1. Like that, θ = -9.91 K, C = 4.73 cm3 mol-1 K, and R = 0.9991 for 2; and θ = -7.98 K, C = 4.83 cm3 mol-1 K, and R = 0.9994 for 3. The moderate negative θ values indicate the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions among adjacent Co(II) ions even if a contribution from the spin-orbit coupling of Co(II) is also present.

elements.content: On the basis of the influence of various shapes and sizes of solvents (DMF, DMA, and DMP), the same 2D frameworks 1–3 have been constructed, and the active replaceable coordinated sites in the 1D channel were discovered. By comparing the sizes of the 1D parallelogram channel, the sizes of the channels (76.84 Å2 of 3 > 74.37 Å2 of 2 > 72.76 Å2 of 1) are determined by the sizes of the solvent molecules (DMP > DMA > DMF). It confirmed that the solvent control on the pore size is feasible on the engineering of PCPs. Complexes 1–3 exhibit good chemical stabilities, and the porous structure in 3 is supported by solvent molecules, which is more stable than 1 and 2 in water and methanol. However, under the same synthesis conditions, the synthesis procedure was not sensitive to hydroxy; the coordinated ability of carbonyl is stronger than the hydroxy. The high yield and purity of the porous complexes 1–3 confirm that the H3cpbda is a good building block for the construction of PCPs. Further research is underway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

On the basis of the influence of various shapes and sizes of solvents (DMF, DMA, and DMP), the same 2D frameworks 1-3 have been constructed, and the active replaceable coordinated sites in the 1D channel were discovered. By comparing the sizes of the 1D parallelogram channel, the sizes of the channels (76.84 Å2 of 3 > 74.37 Å2 of 2 > 72.76 Å2 of 1) are determined by the sizes of the solvent molecules (DMP > DMA > DMF). It confirmed that the solvent control on the pore size is feasible on the engineering of PCPs. Complexes 1-3 exhibit good chemical stabilities, and the porous structure in 3 is supported by solvent molecules, which is more stable than 1 and 2 in water and methanol. However, under the same synthesis conditions, the synthesis procedure was not sensitive to hydroxy; the coordinated ability of carbonyl is stronger than the hydroxy. The high yield and purity of the porous complexes 1-3 confirm that the H3cpbda is a good building block for the construction of PCPs. Further research is underway.

The 2D complexes 1–3 possess the similar skeletons (Figure c). Three Co(II) were bridged by water molecules (O1w) to be a three nuclear clusters, then were connected with six cpbda ligands around, extending to be the 2D layer. The cpbda ligand coordinate with four metal ions can be simplified as a four-connected node. The Co1 and Co2 are two-connected and four-connected nodes. The 2D structure of 1–3 can be described as a (3,4,6)-network with the Point symbol of (3·4·5·62·7)2(3·6·7)2(32·42·52·62·76·9), in Figure d. View along the c axis, the 1D parallelogram channels are shown in 3D framework, with the dimensions of approximately 6.8 × 10.7 Å2 (including van der Walls radii of the atoms) (Figure b) .

{[Co<sub>1.5</sub>(cpbda)(DMA)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·(DMA)}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction shows that 2 crystallizes in monoclinic system with P21 /n space group as well. The asymmetric unit is similar to that of 1, and all the DMF are instead by DMA molecules in 2, as shown in Figure a. The Co–O bonds distances are 2.045(3) (Co1–O9) and 2.195(3) (Co1–O1w) Å; the bond angles around Co(II) cations are in the range of 81.06(14) to 180.00(16)°. Along the c axis, the dimensions of 1D parallelogram channels in 2 is approximately 6.7 × 11.1 Å2 (including van der Walls radii of the atoms) (Figure b).

Thermal Stability Analyses

To identify the thermal stabilities of 1–3, the TGA measurements are carried out (Figure a). The curves show that the structure of 2 is thermally stable until 100 °C and that 1 and 3 are thermally stable until 110 °C. For complex 1, a weight loss of 29.5% (calcd. 29.6%) is observed from 110 to 360 °C, which is attributed to the loss of three coordinated water molecules and two DMF molecules, after 390 °C organic components quickly break down. For 2, the weight loss of 31.8% between 100 and 370 °C is corresponding to the loss of three water molecules; one lattice and one coordinated DMA molecules are lost (calcd. 32.4%), and then rapid decomposition of 2 at 390 °C is observed. The curve of 3 shows that coordinated three water molecules and two DMP molecules are lost at the range of 110 and 340 °C, (obsd. 34.6%; calcd. 34.7%). Up to 380 °C, the organic components decomposed, and complex 1 was chosen, with the nitrogen atmosphere, slowly heated up to 150, 180, 200, 300, and 400 °C, and the temperatures were constant for 2 h. The IR analyses of five heated samples (Figure b) prove that the DMF molecules have not fully went out at a high temperature up to 200 °C, and the variable-temperature PXRD analyses of 1 (Figure S12, ) prove that the 2D porous structure was destroyed before 130 °C; the DMF molecules have not went out. So, the desolvations of 1–3 can hardly be realized to obtain porous 2D structures, and the gas adsorptions have not been further explored.

Magnetic Properties

The antiferromagnetic magnetic behaviors of 1–3 are shown in Figure . The magnetic susceptibilities, χM, of 1–3 were measured in the 2–300 K temperature range. At room temperature, χM T of 1–3 are equal to 4.75, 4.58, and 4.70 cm3 mol–1K, respectively. The values are higher than the value of 3.75 cm3 mol–1K based on two isolated spin-only Co(II) because of the contributions to the susceptibility from orbital angular momentum at high temperature. As the temperature changes from room temperature to 2 K, the χM T values of 1–3 continuously decrease; at 2 K, χM T values of 1.66, 1.63, and 1.89 cm3 mol–1 K are observed. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibilities (1/χM) of 1–3 obey the Curie–Weiss law with χM = C/(T – θ), with θ = −9.47 K, C = 5.51 cm3 mol–1 K, and R = 0.9991 for 1. Like that, θ = −9.91 K, C = 4.73 cm3 mol–1 K, and R = 0.9991 for 2; and θ = −7.98 K, C = 4.83 cm3 mol–1 K, and R = 0.9994 for 3. The moderate negative θ values indicate the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions among adjacent Co(II) ions even if a contribution from the spin–orbit coupling of Co(II) is also present.
cln_elements.clean_text:
The 2D complexes 1-3 possess the similar skeletons (Figure c). Three Co(II) were bridged by water molecules (O1w) to be a three nuclear clusters, then were connected with six cpbda ligands around, extending to be the 2D layer. The cpbda ligand coordinate with four metal ions can be simplified as a four-connected node. The Co1 and Co2 are two-connected and four-connected nodes. The 2D structure of 1-3 can be described as a (3,4,6)-network with the Point symbol of (3⋅4⋅5⋅62⋅7)2(3⋅6⋅7)2(32⋅42⋅52⋅62⋅76⋅9), in Figure d. View along the c axis, the 1D parallelogram channels are shown in 3D framework, with the dimensions of approximately 6.8 × 10.7 Å2 (including van der Walls radii of the atoms) (Figure b) .

{[Co1.5(cpbda)(DMA)(H2O)3]⋅(DMA)} n  (2)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction shows that 2 crystallizes in monoclinic system with P21 /n space group as well. The asymmetric unit is similar to that of 1, and all the DMF are instead by DMA molecules in 2, as shown in Figure a. The Co-O bonds distances are 2.045(3) (Co1-O9) and 2.195(3) (Co1-O1w) Å; the bond angles around Co(II) cations are in the range of 81.06(14) to 180.00(16)°. Along the c axis, the dimensions of 1D parallelogram channels in 2 is approximately 6.7 × 11.1 Å2 (including van der Walls radii of the atoms) (Figure b).

Thermal Stability Analyses

To identify the thermal stabilities of 1-3, the TGA measurements are carried out (Figure a). The curves show that the structure of 2 is thermally stable until 100 °C and that 1 and 3 are thermally stable until 110 °C. For complex 1, a weight loss of 29.5% (calcd. 29.6%) is observed from 110 to 360 °C, which is attributed to the loss of three coordinated water molecules and two DMF molecules, after 390 °C organic components quickly break down. For 2, the weight loss of 31.8% between 100 and 370 °C is corresponding to the loss of three water molecules; one lattice and one coordinated DMA molecules are lost (calcd. 32.4%), and then rapid decomposition of 2 at 390 °C is observed. The curve of 3 shows that coordinated three water molecules and two DMP molecules are lost at the range of 110 and 340 °C, (obsd. 34.6%; calcd. 34.7%). Up to 380 °C, the organic components decomposed, and complex 1 was chosen, with the nitrogen atmosphere, slowly heated up to 150, 180, 200, 300, and 400 °C, and the temperatures were constant for 2 h. The IR analyses of five heated samples (Figure b) prove that the DMF molecules have not fully went out at a high temperature up to 200 °C, and the variable-temperature PXRD analyses of 1 (Figure S12, ) prove that the 2D porous structure was destroyed before 130 °C; the DMF molecules have not went out. So, the desolvations of 1-3 can hardly be realized to obtain porous 2D structures, and the gas adsorptions have not been further explored.

Magnetic Properties

The antiferromagnetic magnetic behaviors of 1-3 are shown in Figure . The magnetic susceptibilities, χM, of 1-3 were measured in the 2-300 K temperature range. At room temperature, χM T of 1-3 are equal to 4.75, 4.58, and 4.70 cm3 mol-1K, respectively. The values are higher than the value of 3.75 cm3 mol-1K based on two isolated spin-only Co(II) because of the contributions to the susceptibility from orbital angular momentum at high temperature. As the temperature changes from room temperature to 2 K, the χM T values of 1-3 continuously decrease; at 2 K, χM T values of 1.66, 1.63, and 1.89 cm3 mol-1 K are observed. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibilities (1/χM) of 1-3 obey the Curie-Weiss law with χM = C/(T - θ), with θ = -9.47 K, C = 5.51 cm3 mol-1 K, and R = 0.9991 for 1. Like that, θ = -9.91 K, C = 4.73 cm3 mol-1 K, and R = 0.9991 for 2; and θ = -7.98 K, C = 4.83 cm3 mol-1 K, and R = 0.9994 for 3. The moderate negative θ values indicate the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions among adjacent Co(II) ions even if a contribution from the spin-orbit coupling of Co(II) is also present.
